  "article_text": [
    "the following square - free algebra @xmath2 associated to an arbitrary vertex labeled graph @xmath1 was defined in @xcite , see also @xcite .",
    "let @xmath1 be a graph without loops on the vertex set @xmath3 ( below we always assume that all graphs might have multiple edges , but no loops ) . throughout the whole paper ,",
    "we fix a field @xmath4 of zero characteristic .",
    "let @xmath5 be the graded commutative algebra over @xmath4 generated by the variables @xmath6 , with the defining relations : @xmath7 let @xmath2 be the subalgebra of @xmath5 generated by the elements @xmath8 for @xmath9 where @xmath10 for the reasons which will be clear soon , we call @xmath2 the _ spanning forests counting algebra _ of @xmath1 .",
    "its hilbert series and the set of defining relations were calculated in @xcite following the initial paper @xcite .",
    "namely , let @xmath11 be the ideal in @xmath12 $ ] generated by the polynomials @xmath13 where @xmath14 ranges over all nonempty subsets in @xmath15 and @xmath16 where @xmath17 is the total number of edges connecting a given vertex @xmath18 with all vertices outside @xmath14 .",
    "thus , @xmath19 is the total number of edges between @xmath14 and the complementary set of vertices @xmath20 . set @xmath21/{\\mathcal { j}}_g.$ ]    observe that since @xmath22 , we can define @xmath2 as the subalgebra of @xmath5 generated by @xmath23 .",
    "we can also define @xmath24 as the quotient algebra of @xmath25 $ ] by the ideal generated by @xmath26 , where @xmath14 runs over all subsets of @xmath27 .",
    "this follows from the relation @xmath28    to describe the hilbert polynomial of @xmath29 we need the following classical notion going back to w.  t.  tutte .",
    "given a simple graph @xmath30 fix an arbitrary linear order of its edges .",
    "now , given a spanning forest @xmath31 in @xmath1 ( i.e. , a subgraph without cycles which includes all vertices of @xmath1 ) and an edge @xmath32 in its complement , we say that @xmath33 is _ externally active_ for @xmath34 if there exists a cycle @xmath35 in @xmath1 such that all edges in @xmath36 belong to @xmath31 and @xmath33 is minimal in @xmath35 with respect to the chosen linear order . the total number of external edges is called the _ external activity _ of @xmath31 .",
    "although the external activity of a given forest / tree in @xmath1 depends on the choice of a linear ordering of edges , the total number of forests / trees with a given external activity is independent of this ordering .",
    "now we are ready to formulate the main result of  @xcite .",
    "[ th : forests][theorems  3 and 4 of @xcite ] for any simple graph @xmath30 algebras @xmath37 and @xmath2 are isomorphic .",
    "the total dimension of these algebras ( as vector spaces over @xmath4 ) is equal to the number of spanning subforests in  @xmath1 .",
    "the dimension of the @xmath38-th graded component of these algebras equals the number of subforests @xmath31 in @xmath1 with external activity @xmath39 . here",
    "@xmath40 ( resp .",
    "@xmath41 ) stands for the number of edges in @xmath1 ( resp .",
    "@xmath31 ) .    in the above notation",
    ", our main object will be the filtered subalgebra @xmath42 defined by the generators : @xmath43 ( notice that we have one more generator here than in the previous case . )    since @xmath44 is obtained by exponentiation of @xmath45 we call @xmath46 the  k - theoretic \" analog of @xmath2 .",
    "our first result is as follows .",
    "define the ideal @xmath47 in @xmath48 $ ] as generated by the polynomials @xmath49 where @xmath14 ranges over all nonempty subsets in @xmath50 and the number @xmath19 is the same as in .",
    "set @xmath51/{\\mathcal { i}}_g.$ ]    [ th:4alg ] for any graph @xmath30 algebras @xmath52 @xmath2 , @xmath53 and @xmath46 are isomorphic as ( non - filtered ) algebras .",
    "moreover , the following stronger statement holds .",
    "[ th : main ] for any graph @xmath1 , algebras @xmath53 and @xmath46 are isomorphic as filtered algebras .",
    "recall that in a recent paper @xcite the first author has shown that @xmath2 contains all information about the matroid of @xmath1 and only it .",
    "namely ,    [ nenashev][theorem  5 of @xcite ] given two graphs @xmath54 and @xmath55 algebras @xmath56 and @xmath57 are isomorphic if and only if the matroids of @xmath54 and @xmath58 coincide .",
    "( the latter isomorphism can be thought of either as graded or as non - graded , the statement holds in both cases . )    on the other hand , filtered algebras @xmath53 and @xmath46 contain complete information about @xmath1 .",
    "[ th : isom ] given two graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 without isolated vertices , @xmath59 and @xmath60 are isomorphic as filtered algebras if and only if @xmath54 and @xmath58 are isomorphic .",
    "the structure of this paper is as follows . in ",
    "2 we prove new results formulated above . in   3",
    "we discuss hilbert series of similar algebras defined by other sets of generators . in   4 we discuss ",
    "k - theoretic \" analogs of algebras counting spanning trees . finally , in   5 we present a number of open problems .",
    "_ acknowledgements . _ the study of @xmath53 and @xmath46 was initiated by the second author jointly with professor a.  n.  kirillov during his visit to stockholm in october - november 2009 supported by the swedish royal academy .",
    "the second author is happy to acknowledge the importance of this visit for the present project and to dedicate this paper to professor kirillov .",

    "let us look at what happens with the ideal @xmath80 under the action of @xmath86 .",
    "for a given @xmath76 , consider the generator @xmath89 then , @xmath90    @xmath91 the factor @xmath92 is a formal power series starting with the constant term @xmath93 .",
    "hence the last factor in the right - hand side of the latter expression is an invertible power series .",
    "thus , the generator @xmath81 is mapped by @xmath86 to the product @xmath94 where @xmath95 is an invertible series .",
    "this implies @xmath96 .",
    "hence algebras @xmath53 and @xmath24 are isomorphic .    by lemmas  [ lem : isck ] ,  [ lem : isbd ] and theorem  [ th : forests ]",
    ", we get that all four algebras are isomorphic to each other . furthermore , by theorem  [ th : forests ] , we know that their total dimension over @xmath4 is the number of subforests in @xmath1 .    theorem  [ th : main ] now follows from theorem  [ th:4alg ] .",

    "it is clear that @xmath101 preserves the filtration .",

    "our proof of theorem  [ th : isom ] uses the following technical lemma which should be obvious to the specialists .",
    "[ gr - edges ] let @xmath140 be the set of edges of some graph @xmath1 without isolated vertices . if we know the following information :    1 .   which pairs @xmath141 of edges are multiple ,",
    "i.e. , connect the same pair of vertices ; 2 .",
    "which pairs @xmath141 of edges have exactly one common vertex ; 3 .   which triples @xmath142 of edges",
    "form a triangle ,    then we can reconstruct @xmath1 up to an isomorphism .    assume the contrary , i.e. , that there exist two non - isomorphic graphs @xmath1 and @xmath143 such that there exists a bijection @xmath86 of their edge sets @xmath140 and @xmath144 preserving ( 1 ) - ( 3 ) . assume that under this bijection an edge @xmath145 corresponds to the edge @xmath146",
    ". additionally assume that @xmath147 .",
    "now we construct an isomorphism between @xmath1 and @xmath143 .",
    "let us split the vertices of @xmath1 into two subsets : @xmath148 where @xmath149 are all vertices which are incident to some pair of non - multiple edges .",
    "let us construct a bijection @xmath86 between the vertices of @xmath1 and @xmath143 , which extends the given bijection @xmath86 of edges , i.e. , for any @xmath150 , @xmath151    at first we define it on @xmath149 .",
    "namely , given a vertex @xmath152 choose two non - multiple edges @xmath153 and @xmath154 incident to it , and define @xmath155 as a common vertex of @xmath156 and @xmath157 we need to show that @xmath155 does not depend on the choice of @xmath153 and @xmath154 .",
    "it is enough to check it for a pair @xmath153 and @xmath158 , where @xmath159 is another edge incident to @xmath160 . indeed ,",
    "if @xmath161 has no common vertex with both @xmath162 and @xmath163 , then @xmath162 , @xmath163 and @xmath164 form a triangle in @xmath143 ( because @xmath164 has a common vertex with @xmath162 and with @xmath163 ) .",
    "hence , @xmath153 , @xmath154 and @xmath159 form a triangle in @xmath1 , but they have a common vertex @xmath160 . contradiction .",
    "now we need to extend @xmath86 to vertices belonging to @xmath165 .",
    "note that each vertex @xmath166 has exactly one adjacent vertex .",
    "there are two possibilities .",
    "@xmath167 _ adjacent vertex @xmath168 of @xmath160 belongs to @xmath149 .",
    "_ consider the edge @xmath169 ( there might be several such edges , but this is not important , because in @xmath143 they are also multiple . )",
    "knowing the image @xmath170 and the vertex @xmath171 , we define @xmath155 as the vertex of @xmath170 different from @xmath171 .",
    "@xmath172 _ adjacent vertex @xmath168 of @xmath160 belongs to @xmath173 . _",
    "consider edge @xmath174 knowing @xmath170 , we define @xmath171 and @xmath155 as the vertices of edge  @xmath170 ( not important which is mapped to which ) .",
    "since @xmath143 has no isolated vertices and each edge @xmath175 has exactly two incident vertices from @xmath176 , we get that @xmath177 is surjective .",
    "hence , @xmath177 is an isomorphism ( otherwise it must be non - injective on vertices and , hence , @xmath178 ) . therefore @xmath1 and @xmath143 are isomorphic .",

    "@xmath63-th vertex of graph @xmath1 _ , and we call @xmath187 the _",
    "@xmath127-th vertex of graph @xmath143_.    since @xmath188 $ ] and @xmath189 $ ] determine the same graded structure , then , in particular , @xmath190 additionally , by lemma  [ pr - basis ] , @xmath188 $ ] and @xmath189 $ ] are nilpotents , implying that @xmath191    firstly , we need to show that each edge - element @xmath110 belongs to at most two different @xmath192 s . assume the contrary , i.e. , that @xmath110 belongs to @xmath193 and @xmath194 .",
    "then there exist three distinct non - zero coefficients @xmath195 such that @xmath110 does not belong to @xmath196 .",
    "moreover , for generic distinct non - zero coefficients @xmath197 , element @xmath198 ( @xmath199 ) belongs to @xmath200 if and only if @xmath198 belongs to at least one of @xmath193 and @xmath194 .",
    "hence by lemma  [ lem - degree ] , @xmath201 but at the same time , by lemma  [ pr - basis ]  ( 3 ) , they should coincide , contradiction .    by lemma  [ pr - basis ] , for any @xmath202 $ ]",
    ", the degree @xmath203 equals to the valency of @xmath192 .",
    "therefore , @xmath204 because each edge - element is included in at most two @xmath192 .",
    "since @xmath205 , we conclude that @xmath206 furthermore , by lemma  [ pr - basis ] ( 2 ) , each element @xmath207 belongs exactly to two vertices from @xmath208 $ ] with the opposite coefficients . since @xmath209 we can additionally assume that the number of pairs of non - multiple edges which have a common vertex in @xmath143 is bigger than that in @xmath1 .",
    "so far we have constructed a bijection between the edges of @xmath1 and the edges of @xmath143 .",
    "we want to prove that this bijection provides a graph isomorphism .",
    "we will achieve this as a result of the 5 claims collected in the following proposition which is closely related to lemma   [ gr - edges ] .    [ prop:5claims ]",
    "the following facts hold .    1 .   _",
    "if @xmath210 and @xmath211 have no common vertex in @xmath1 , then they have no common vertex in  @xmath143 as well .",
    "if @xmath210 and @xmath211 are multiple edges in  @xmath1 , then they are multiple edges in  @xmath143 as well .",
    "if @xmath210 and @xmath211 have exactly one common vertex in @xmath1 , then they have exactly one common vertex in  @xmath143 as well .",
    "if @xmath210 , @xmath211 and @xmath212 form a star in  @xmath1 , then they form a star in  @xmath143 as well . _",
    "( three edges form a star if they have one common vertex and their three other ends are distinct . )",
    "if @xmath210 , @xmath211 and @xmath212 form a triangle in  @xmath1 , then they form a triangle in  @xmath143 as well .",
    "_    to prove ( 1 ) , assume the contrary , i.e. , assume that @xmath210 and @xmath211 belong to @xmath213 ( and denote the corresponding coefficients by @xmath214 and @xmath215 resp . ) .",
    "since elements @xmath216 have no monomial @xmath217 , then @xmath218 have no monomial @xmath217 as well ( since their spans coincide ) .",
    "then @xmath219 contains the monomial @xmath217 with the coefficient  @xmath220 .    by lemma  [ pr - basis ]",
    "( 2 ) , we have @xmath221 , then there exists @xmath222 , k\\neq i$ ] such that @xmath223 contains the monomial @xmath224 with a non - zero coefficient",
    ". then @xmath194 must contain @xmath210 and @xmath211 ( since @xmath194 does not contains @xmath217 ) .",
    "hence , @xmath194 has @xmath210 and @xmath211 with coefficients @xmath225 and @xmath226 resp",
    ". therefore @xmath223 contains monomial @xmath217 with the coefficient @xmath227 .",
    "thus the sum @xmath228 contains @xmath217 with coefficient @xmath229 , contradiction .    to prove ( 2 ) ,",
    "consider the map from @xmath230 to @xmath231 , sending an element from the span to the pair of coefficients of @xmath210 and @xmath211 resp . since edges @xmath232 and @xmath233 are multiple in @xmath1 , the image of this map has dimension @xmath93 . if @xmath210 and @xmath211 are not multiple in  @xmath143 , then the image of the map from @xmath234 has dimension @xmath235",
    ".    to prove ( 3 ) , observe that we have already settled claims 1 and 2 , and also we additionally assumed that the number of pairs of edges which have a common vertex in @xmath143 is bigger than that in @xmath1 .",
    "then each such pair of edges from @xmath1 is mapped to the pair of edges from @xmath143 with the same property .    to prove ( 4 ) ,",
    "consider the map from @xmath230 to @xmath236 , sending an element in the span to the triple of coefficients of @xmath237 @xmath211 and @xmath212 resp .",
    "the image of this map has dimension @xmath238 .",
    "however if @xmath210 , @xmath211 and @xmath212 form a triangle in  @xmath143 , then the image of the map from @xmath239 has dimension @xmath235 .",
    "proof of ( 5 ) is   similar to that of ( 4 ) .",
    "now applying lemma  [ gr - edges ] we finish our proof of theorem  [ th : isom ] .",
    "in this section we will consider the hilbert series of other filtered algebras similar to @xmath46 .",
    "( recall that the hilbert series of a filtered algebra is , by definition , the hilbert series of its associated graded algebra . )",
    "let @xmath240 be a univariate polynomial or a formal power series over @xmath4 .",
    "we define the subalgebra @xmath241_g\\subset \\phi_g$ ] as generated by @xmath93 together with @xmath242    for @xmath243 , @xmath241_g$ ] coincides with @xmath2 . for @xmath244 , @xmath241_g$ ]",
    "coincides with @xmath46 .",
    "obviously , the filtered algebra @xmath241_g$ ] does not depend on the constant term of  @xmath245 from now on , we assume that @xmath246 has no constant term , since for any @xmath247 such that @xmath248 is constant , the filtered algebras @xmath241_g$ ] and @xmath249_g$ ] are the same .",
    "let @xmath240 be any polynomial with a non - vanishing linear term .",
    "then algebras @xmath2 and @xmath241_g$ ] coincide as subalgebras of @xmath5 .",
    "the argument is the same as in the proof of lemma  [ lem : isck ] .",
    "we only need to change @xmath250 to @xmath246 and @xmath251 to @xmath252 .",
    "[ th : isom - f ] let @xmath240 be any polynomial with non - vanishing linear and quadratic terms .",
    "then given two simple graphs @xmath54 and @xmath55 @xmath241_{g_1}$ ] and @xmath241_{g_2}$ ] are isomorphic as filtered algebras if and only if @xmath54 and @xmath58 are isomorphic graphs .",
    "repeat the proof of theorem  [ th : isom ] .      since @xmath253 for any @xmath63",
    ", we can always truncate any polynomial ( or a formal power series ) @xmath240 at degree @xmath254 without changing @xmath241_g$ ] .",
    "therefore , for a given graph @xmath1 , it suffices to consider @xmath240 as a polynomial of degrees less than or equal to @xmath40 . to simplify our notation ,",
    "let us write @xmath255 instead of @xmath256_g}$ ]",
    ".    given a graph @xmath1 , consider the space of polynomials of degree less than or equal to @xmath40 and the corresponding hilbert series .",
    "[ pr - hil ] in the above notation , for generic polynomials @xmath240 of degree at most @xmath40 , the hilbert series @xmath255 is the same .",
    "this generic hilbert series ( denoted by @xmath257 below ) is maximal in the majorization partial order among all @xmath258 where @xmath247 runs over the set of all formal power series with non - vanishing linear term .",
    "recall that , by definition , a sequence @xmath259 is _ bigger _ than @xmath260 in the majorization partial order if and only if , for any @xmath261 , @xmath262 more information about the majorization partial order can be found in e.g. @xcite .",
    "note that , for a function @xmath263 the sum of the first @xmath264 entries of its hilbert series @xmath255 equals the dimension of @xmath265 it is obvious that , for a generic @xmath263 this dimension is maximal .",
    "since all hilbert series @xmath255 are polynomials of degree at most @xmath266 then the required property has to be checked only for @xmath267 .",
    "therefore it is obvious that , for generic @xmath240 , their hilbert series is maximal in the majorization order .",
    "     we know that the hilbert series of the graded algebra @xmath2 is a specialization of the tutte polynomial of @xmath1 .",
    "however we can not calculate the hilbert series of @xmath46 from the tutte polynomial of @xmath1 , because there exists a pair of graphs @xmath268 with the same tutte polynomial and different @xmath269 and @xmath270 , see example  [ examp ] .",
    "additionally , notice that , in general , @xmath271 .",
    "analogously we can not calculate generic hilbert series @xmath272 from the tutte polynomial of @xmath1 , see example  [ examp ] .",
    "[ examp ]        consider two graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 presented in fig .",
    "it is well - known that @xmath54 and @xmath58 have isomorphic matroids and hence , the same tutte polynomial .",
    "therefore , the hilbert series of @xmath56 and @xmath57 coincide .",
    "namely , @xmath273 however , the hilbert series of  k - theoretic \" algebras are distinct .",
    "namely @xmath274 @xmath275 moreover their generic hilbert series are also distinct and different from their  k - theoretic \" hilbert series .",
    "namely , @xmath276 @xmath277 putting our information together we get , @xmath278 where @xmath279 denotes the majorization partial order .",
    "for an arbitrary loopless graph @xmath1 on the vertex set @xmath280 let @xmath281 be the graded commutative algebra over a given field @xmath4 generated by the variables @xmath6 , with the defining relations : @xmath282 @xmath283 where a subgraph @xmath284 is called _ slim _ if its complement @xmath285 is connected .",
    "let @xmath286 be the subalgebra of @xmath281 generated by the elements @xmath287 for @xmath9 where @xmath288 is given by .",
    "( notice that @xmath289 and @xmath290 are defined by exactly the same formula but in different ambient algebras . )",
    "algebra @xmath286 will be called the _ spanning trees counting algebra_ of @xmath1 and is , obviously , the quotient of @xmath2 modulo the set of relations @xmath291 over all non - slim subgraphs @xmath284 .",
    "its defining set of relations is very natural and resembles that of .",
    "namely , define the ideal @xmath292 in @xmath12 $ ] as generated by the polynomials : @xmath293 where @xmath14 ranges over all nonempty subsets in @xmath15 and the number @xmath19 is the same as in .",
    "set @xmath294/{\\mathcal { j}}_g^t.$ ] one of the results of @xcite claims the following .",
    "[ th : trees ] [ theorems  9.1 and corollary  10.5 of @xcite ] for any simple graph @xmath1 on the set of vertices @xmath295 algebras @xmath296 and @xmath286 are isomorphic .",
    "their total dimension is equal to the number of spanning trees in @xmath1 .",
    "the dimension @xmath297 of the @xmath38-th graded component of @xmath296 equals the number of spanning trees @xmath298 in @xmath1 with external activity @xmath299 .",
    "similarly to the above , we can define the filtered algebra @xmath300 which is isomorphic to @xmath286 as a non - filtered algebra .",
    "namely , @xmath301 is defined by the generators : @xmath302    the first result of this section is as follows .",
    "define the ideal @xmath303 $ ] as generated by the polynomials : @xmath304 where @xmath14 ranges over all nonempty proper subsets in @xmath50 and the number @xmath19 is the same as in , together with the generator @xmath305 set @xmath306/{\\mathcal { i}}_g^t.$ ]    we present two results similar to the case of spanning forests .",
    "[ th:4alg - tree ] for any simple graph @xmath30 algebras @xmath307 @xmath286 , @xmath308 and @xmath301 are isomorphic as ( non - filtered ) algebras .",
    "their total dimension is equal to the number of spanning trees in @xmath1 .",
    "the proof is similar to that of theorem  [ th:4alg ] .",
    "algebras @xmath286 and @xmath301 coincide as subalgebras of @xmath281 ( but they have different filtrations ) ; algebras @xmath286 and @xmath309 are isomorphic by theorem  [ th : trees ] .",
    "the proof of the isomorphism between @xmath308 and @xmath309 is the same as above ; we only need to add the variable @xmath310 to @xmath309 .",
    "[ th : main - tree ] for any simple graph @xmath1 , algebras @xmath308 and @xmath301 are isomorphic as filtered algebras .",
    "similar to the above proof of theorem  [ th : main ] .    to move further , we need to give a definition .",
    "let @xmath1 be a connected graph .",
    "we define its @xmath311-subgraph @xmath312 as the subgraph with following edges and vertices :    * @xmath313 if @xmath33 is not a bridge ( i.e. , @xmath314 is still connected ) , * @xmath315 if there is an edge @xmath316 incident to @xmath160 .    in general",
    ", @xmath317 contains more information about @xmath1 than its matroid , because there exist graphs with isomorphic matroids and non - isomorphic @xmath311-subgraphs , see figure  [ delta - g1g2 ] . recall that in a recent paper @xcite , the first author has shown that @xmath286 depends only on the bridge - free matroid of @xmath1 .",
    "namely ,    [ nenashev - tree][proposition  12 of @xcite ] for any two connected graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 with isomorphic bridge - free matroids ( matroids of their @xmath311-subgraphs ) , algebras @xmath318 and @xmath319 are isomorphic .",
    "unfortunately , we can not prove the converse implication at present although we conjecture that is should hold as well , see conjecture  [ cut - spaces ] in   [ sec : final ] . in case of filtered algebra @xmath320 and @xmath321",
    "we can also prove an appropriate result only in one direction , see proposition  [ pr : isom - tree ] .    similarly to ",
    "3 we can to define @xmath241^t_g\\subset \\phi_g$ ] . let @xmath240 be a univariate polynomial or a formal power series over @xmath4 .",
    "we define the subalgebra @xmath241^t_g\\subset \\phi_g$ ] as generated by @xmath93 and by @xmath322    [ pr : isom - tree ] for univariate polynomial @xmath240 and any two connected graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 with isomorphic @xmath311-subgraphs @xmath323 and @xmath324 , algebras @xmath241^t_{g_1}$ ] and @xmath241^t_{g_2}$ ] are isomorphic as filtered algebras .",
    "additionally , @xmath320 and @xmath321 are isomorphic as filtered algebras .",
    "note that if @xmath1 has a bridge @xmath33 , then filtered algebra @xmath241^t_{g}$ ] is the cartesian product of filtered algebras @xmath241^t_{g'}$ ] and @xmath241^t_{g''}$ ] , where @xmath143 and @xmath325 are connected component of @xmath314 .",
    "thus filtered algebra @xmath241^t_{g}$ ] is the cartesian product of such filtered algebras corresponding to the connected components of the @xmath311-subgraph of @xmath1 .    therefore if connected graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 have isomorphic @xmath311-subgraphs , then their filtered algebras @xmath241^t_{g_1}$ ] and @xmath241^t_{g_2}$ ] are isomorphic .    [ rem - tree ]    in general case",
    "we can not prove that these algebras distinguish graphs with different @xmath311-subgraphs .",
    "the proof of theorem  [ th : isom ] does not work for two reasons .",
    "firstly , @xmath326 is not the degree of the @xmath63-th vertex in @xmath1 .",
    "secondly , even if we can construct a similar bijection between edges , we do not have an analog of proposition  [ prop:5claims ] .",
    "since in the proof we consider coefficients of monomial @xmath217 , in case when @xmath327 and @xmath328 are not bridges and when @xmath329 is a cut , this monomial can still lie in the ideal .",
    "it is possible to construct such a bijection in a smaller set of graphs , namely for graphs such that , for any edge @xmath33 in the graph , there is another edge @xmath175 which is multiple to @xmath33 . for such graphs we do not have the second problem , because if @xmath329 is a cut , then @xmath232 and @xmath233 are multiple edges .",
    "so , instead of the actual converse of proposition  [ pr : isom - tree ] , we can prove the converse in the latter situation , but we do not present this result here .",
    "[ pr - hil - tree ] in the above notation , for generic polynomials @xmath240 of degree at most @xmath40 , the hilbert series @xmath256^t_g}$ ] is the same .",
    "this generic hilbert series ( denoted by @xmath330 below ) is maximal in the majorization partial order among @xmath331^t_g}$ ] for @xmath247 running over the set of power series with non - vanishing linear term .",
    "see the proof of proposition  [ pr - hil ] .",
    "[ delta ]    consider two graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 , see fig .",
    "[ delta - g1g2 ] .",
    "it is easy to check that subgraphs @xmath323 and @xmath324 have isomorphic matroids , implying that algebras @xmath318 and @xmath319 are isomorphic",

    "@xmath332 the hilbert series of  k - theoretic \" algebras are distinct , namely @xmath333 @xmath334 these graphs are ",
    "small \" , so their generic hilbert series coincides with the  k - theoretic \" one .",
    "putting our information together , we get @xmath335",
    "at first , we formulate several problems in case of spanning forests ; their analogs for spanning trees are straight - forward .    for",
    "which functions @xmath240 besides @xmath336 and @xmath337 , one can present relations in @xmath241_{g}$ ] for any graph @xmath1 in a simple way ? in other words , for which @xmath263 one can define an algebra similar to @xmath24 and @xmath53 ?          describe combinatorial properties of @xmath255 when @xmath240 is a function starting with a monomial of degree bigger than @xmath93 , i.e. @xmath339 ?",
    "in particular , calculate the total dimension of @xmath241_g$ ] .",
    "do there exist non - isomorphic graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 such that , for any polynomial @xmath246 , the hilbert series @xmath340 and @xmath341 coincide ?",
    "in other words , does the collection of hilbert series @xmath255 taken over all formal series @xmath240 determine @xmath1 up to isomorphism ?",
    "@xcite ] [ cut - spaces ] algebras @xmath318 and @xmath319 for graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 are isomorphic if and only if their bridge - free matroids are isomorphic , where the bridge - free matroid is the graphical matroid of @xmath311-subgraph .",
    "which class of graphs satisfies the property that if two graphs @xmath54 and @xmath58 from this class have isomorphic @xmath320 and @xmath321 , then their @xmath311-subgraphs are isomorphic . in other words",
    ", can one classify all pairs @xmath342 of connected graphs , which has isomorphic filtered algebras @xmath320 and @xmath321 ? ( the same problem for @xmath241_{g_1}^t$ ] and @xmath241_{g_2}^t$ ] , where @xmath343 )              a .",

    "differential topology , infinite - dimensional lie algebras , and applications , 227235 , amer .",
    "ser . 2 , 194 , amer .",
    "soc . , providence , ri , 1999    b .",

  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in this paper we study a filtered  @xmath0-theoretical \" analog of a graded algebra associated to any loopless graph @xmath1 which was introduced in @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> we show that two such filtered algebras are isomorphic if and only if their graphs are isomorphic . </S>",
    "<S> we also study a large family of filtered generalizations of the latter graded algebra which includes the above  </S>",
    "<S> @xmath0-theoretical \" analog . </S>"
  ]
}
